title: 105_s2207
content: The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" aims to empower the Attorney General to prevent mergers and acquisitions that could harm competition in the telecommunications industry. It amends the Clayton Act to address restraints of trade specifically related to telecommunications. The "Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998" defines a large local telephone company as one serving more than 5% of telephone access lines in the US. It prohibits mergers or acquisitions of such companies unless they promote competition and meet certain requirements set by the Attorney General and the Federal Communications Commission. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 defines a large local telephone company as serving over 5% of telephone access lines in the US. Mergers or acquisitions of such companies must promote competition and meet requirements set by the Attorney General and the Federal Communications Commission. The Attorney General must report findings on the impact of mergers on competition in the telecommunications industry to Congress within 10 days. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 outlines the process for large local telephone companies proposing mergers or acquisitions, requiring applications to be filed with the Attorney General and the FCC simultaneously. District courts have jurisdiction to prevent mergers inconsistent with competition findings. The Antitrust Improvements Act of 1998 grants jurisdiction to district courts and the Attorney General to prevent mergers or acquisitions that do not meet competition requirements outlined in the Act. The Attorney General can initiate legal proceedings in any district court in the US to seek injunctive relief if a proposed merger fails to meet the specified conditions. SEC. 4 of the Act preserves existing authorities related to antitrust laws and FCC regulations for mergers, acquisitions, and affiliations of large incumbent local exchange carriers. SEC. 5 specifies that the Act applies to mergers or acquisitions of controlling interests in large local telephone companies occurring after the Act's enactment date.
